Manager tried to explain something about an air handler but that is an excuse. No one does anything about wild mice and roach people. Manager has “tried” to take care of it. pros: I am a self-motivated person. I am a hard worker who is committed to my work. I do well working under pressure. I take pride in my work and I love to learn. pros: There is a nice Atrium available to patients and staff.  Most of the doctors are wonderful.

You would expect a place like Joslin to modern and cutting edge.  Surprisingly it is not.  Management of the clinic lives in a bubble which no one has bothered to leave in over a decade.  The way they handle all administrative paperwork and prescription requests is ridiculous.  I honestly feel sorry for the patients.  Maybe they have just never gone to another medical facility so they don't know an average appointment should not take 4 hours after waiting 6 months to get it. 
Hey Joslin would it kill you to put a few magazines in your waiting area?  Maybe a TV so people waiting can at least watch something other than those 10 year old video shorts that just loop and play over and over and over again.

cons: Awful place to work. Management is stale and completely out of touch with current business practices. Refusal to embrace technology will be the downfall of this organization. For people with Diabetes coming here for care, it is unparalleled - but the people working her who are trying support that financial loss are seriously under appreciated and without resources to truly achieve that goal. One of the worst jobs I have ever had.

review_title: Deep silos in this organization - your experience is very location specific
pros: Joslin has a good name with a Harvard affiliation and a long history of Diabetes care. They have a unique care model and provide very high quality care. In addition they are one of the largest diabetes research centers in the world with a lot of smart people working there. Its a fairly small organization all in one building so it can become like a family. There are a lot of very nice people here who passionately care about diabetes.
cons:
I think, like most places, the problems come down to management. Joslin has very deep silos that don't communicate well. There are at least three - Research, the clinic, and Joslin Health Solutions but other parts of Joslin exist outside those silos such as development and the office of commercialization. Research is essentially a different company in the same building that has no interactions with anyone. 

As of this writing (May 2014) the clinic and JHS are being transformed in some way that is yet unclear to bring them closer together. 

Joslin struggles with several different areas one of them being management. It seems they just go after ever single different offer that comes along even if it doesn't align at all with existing business lines. For that reason a lot of work is done to recreate the wheel and then just use it a few times. Also, IT resources here are tough to come by although they have been investing in hardware over the last couple of years. Finance is also a department where invoices get processed very slowly.

review_title: Started with high hopes, but a chaotic structure made the experience disappointing
pros: Working for an organization that is focused on a rampant disease that does not receive the national attention that it should.  Being a part of that mission is rewarding and gratifying
cons: Lack of unified focus on the mission of the organization, inability to overcome the silos that exist which threaten the organization as a whole, a curious organizational structure that seems to slow progress rather than accelerate it

pros: Great opportunity to work with and learn from basic scientists who are well versed and accomplished in a variety of subject matter. A very international work community, which is really enjoyable - I learned a lot about a variety of different cultures and can now say I have connections with scientist worldwide. Good opportunity to learn about the work from some of the world's leading scientist and noble prize winners. Benefits offered were good.
cons: The pay offered is not a living wage for the Boston-metropolitan area. Not very much room for growth, at least for a research assistant, unless you go back to school.  The IT department is very inefficient and some employees (most notably the director of IT) are hard to work with. I had a very unprofessional interaction with the head of IT during my time at Joslin during which he yelled at me for something I held no responsibility for. The Animal Facilities are poorly run: during my time I witnessed a lot of health hazards to workers and the mice themselves including vast temperature differences in rooms, poor ventilation, and a leaking roof. Joslin seems to have a new president every few years - I feel the organization needs new leadership and president that is committed to hearing the current problems of the institution and is motivated to fix them and make Joslin a more modern, relevant diabetes research institution and clinic.
